qas.question: In this theory, what action evokes an emotion?
What sort of response does the stimulus cause?
How is the stimulus interpreted by the mind?
In the James-Lange theory, what causes emotions?
In this theory, what action doesn't evoke an emotion?
What sort of response doesn't the stimulus cause?
How is the stimulus not interpreted by the mind?
In the James-Lange theory, what doesn't cause emotions?

context: An example of this theory in action would be as follows: An emotion-evoking <a0_0><b4_0>stimulus<b4_0/><a0_0/> (snake) triggers a pattern of <a1_0><b5_0>physiological<b5_0/><a1_0/> response (increased heart rate, faster breathing, etc.), which is interpreted <a2_0>as a <b6_0>particular emotion<b6_0/><a2_0/> (fear). This theory is supported by experiments in which by manipulating the bodily state induces a desired emotional state. Some people may believe that emotions give rise to emotion-specific actions: e.g. "I'm crying because I'm sad," or "I ran away because I was scared." The issue with the James–Lange theory is that of causation (<a3_0><b7_0>bodily states<b7_0/><a3_0/> causing emotions and being a priori), not that of the bodily influences on emotional experience (which can be argued and is still quite prevalent today in biofeedback studies and embodiment theory).
